ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I was able to improve my speaking, writing, reading, and listening skills in Mandarin Chinese. I saw the greatest improvement in my speaking because I was able to contribute to discussions and also participate in conversations.
Developed greater fluency in Chinese writing, speaking, listening, and reading.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: While the course does assign a lot of work to the students, it is to our benefit. Through the small quizzes that are assigned every morning, I was forced to study every night and thereby saw a huge improvement in my Chinese in just one semester! Sometimes, the classes can become a bit routine, but I like knowing what to expect from each lesson when I walk into the classroom. Overall, the course is wonderful!
Full immersion helps to accelerate language learning, and daily exercises help allow retention of new knowledge. However, sometimes there seems to be too much repetition.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, I recommend the course. CHNS 132 is an amazing class for students that know how to speak and listen in Chinese, but may have trouble reading and writing in Chinese. It is suited to either students that come from Chinese heritage backgrounds or have taken enough classes in high school to be fluent enough to hold conversations that include many idioms and colloquial phrases.
Yes definitely if you are a heritage speaker because you will find many people like you that have had experience with Chinese.
